In a classroom of your community, find a peer to interview. If you can't find a peer, consider inviting someone else for this interview if, for example, your class is much larger than the other classes in the community.
If you are not able to travel to a classroom today, a good place to interview a peer is on a video call (such as Zoom or Google Meet). To do so, invite a peer (perhaps via WhatsApp or email) for a video call interview. After the interview has concluded, write down your peer's responses.
If you cannot find a peer, find some other persons who you can interview for your class project.
a. Use questions found in this unit.
b. Come up with questions yourself.
c. Invite a person to ask the questions. You can, for example, find the answers to the questions from another student. You might find it helpful to write the questions and the answers in a document and share the document with your classmates.
d. The interview could be done on paper, during which time a recording could then be made. Or, it could be done on Zoom or another software so that a recording can be done automatically.
e. If you make a video and upload it to YouTube, you can link to it in your document (above).
f. If you write down the answers in a text (or perhaps a document on Google Docs) that can then be viewed here, here's how:
1. Go to: https://www.freeconvert.com/youtube-to-txt
2. Paste the following address in the address field: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Y4wb6KWV8Q and click on "Convert"
Then, you should have a text file which can be placed in your file section of this site. Note: You'll need a Google account to download it.
f1. If there is any text (such as an intro of the video) at the beginning of the video and if there is some music in the video that you'd like to remove, just go to: https://www.youtube.com/findusertag?st=1&tag= and in the field "YT User Tag:" enter the name of the user and in the field "YT Video Tag:" enter the video tag and click on "Search." Note: a video can have different tags. 3. Once you've found the address, copy that address and paste it into the "Start conversion from" box on the site. You should see the video. You can then copy and paste the link so that it becomes an active link.
g. You can add a title to the text (in YouTube there are two title parts) and you can also add tags to the text so that it has a searchable key word. In order to find the tags, you have to go to the "Transcripts" tab on the video. Under the video, you'll see a button that when clicked will give you another list of tags (i.e., "Mix."

In YouTube, in the video section go to the settings tab and click on that. Then, in "Edit" click on "Edit Video Info." Now you'll be on a page where you'll see the title. You can edit the title and also you can add some tags. You can then add a description and then preview the changes and save them.
You can also choose which chapters of the video will be downloaded.

c. Click on "Transcripts" tab, which will give you a list of the transcripts of the video. Scan the transcript and look for sections of conversations that you'd like to download (and there's one at 0:05 for this example - "The interview will last for a little over 25 minutes." )
d. Next click on the arrow that points down, and a pop-up window will appear.
Once a popup will appear, press "Transcript," and then you can click on the downloaded section of the conversation and the full conversation will be downloaded in a transcript that you can print.
Note: The number of transcripts (such as those in YouTube) depends on the user and on what the user has done previously. Some users will upload their transcripts every time they get a chance so that people can download them and use them in a variety of ways.
e. The transcripts will download as a .txt file. If you want to create a video or an audio of the interview, then you may need to upload it to a site for uploading videos, such as YouTube. To do so, you should create an account on YouTube which will allow you to upload videos. After the video has been uploaded (which can take up to 24 hours for the file to be uploaded) you can then download the video and share it.
You can create video by using a program such as FL Studio which will allow you to upload a file and then create a video out of it.
To edit the video in a program such as FL Studio, you'll need to know how to edit videos. In this video, you'll see how to create a video by taking audio, and adding some effects to it. You won't, of course, be adding the effects that are shown in the video.
g. If you prefer to use an audio only program, such as Audacity, you can first use a text-to-speech program to read a transcript and then save it as a wav or mp3. If there is some background noise in the interview, you can reduce the background noise in Audacity or similar programs.
h. If you're using a transcript, you'll likely have to convert the transcript to an audio file. You can do this is by downloading the transcript and reading it so that you'll learn it by heart. Then, you can read it by adding it into Audacity, or into a video editing software so that it creates an audio file. Then, you can take out all the sounds that are not the sound of the human voice and the background noise. This will give you more control over the sound of the interview. If there's heavy background noise it may require more than one attempt to get it right.
i. Once you have your audio it can then be used anywhere in a video or in an audio, in an animation. This can be done in a variety of ways. One way is to import the audio into the software. In that import, you can choose certain options of how the audio will play. If you select "wav" as the audio format, then you have greater control over the audio. It may be that you record audio and decide that you want to delete something in the audio and do so by editing the audio, but if you import an audio into the software, then you have more control over what is recorded and thus you have more control over the sound. You can then export that audio to other purposes.
d. Now if you want to create a video you'll need to download your audio and then use a video editing program such as FL Studio to add both your audio and your video to the mix.
In this program there are other options of what you can do with your video. You can add effects to it and you can add other things such as music to the video.
There are other video editing programs such as Adobe Premiere, which allow you to edit audio and video together (or with other effects, such as music). Surgical oncology is a specialized field of medicine that focuses on the treatment of cancer through surgery. In order to become a surgical oncologist, one must first complete a residency in general surgery. After completing the residency, the surgeon will then complete a fellowship in surgical oncology.
There are a number of benefits to becoming a surgical oncologist. For example, surgical oncologists are typically among the highest paid surgeons. They also have the opportunity to work in a variety of settings, including universities, private practices, and hospitals.
Although becoming a surgical oncologist can be challenging, it can also be very rewarding. This is particularly true for those who enjoy working with cancer patients and have a passion for surgery.
Ultimately, becoming a surgical oncologist takes hard work and dedication. However, it is also an incredibly gratifying career choice for those who are looking for a challenge and the opportunity to make a difference in the lives of their patients.
There are a few steps that you need to take in order to become a surgical oncologist. First, you will need to complete medical school and a residency in general surgery. After that, you can pursue a fellowship in surgical oncology. This will allow you to specialize in treating cancer with surgery.
In order to become a surgical oncologist, you must have a strong grasp of cancer biology and the latest surgical techniques for treating cancer. You will also need to be highly experienced in managing cancer patients during and after surgery.
Some of the required qualifications for becoming a surgical oncologist include:
– 4 years of medical school
– 3-year residency in general surgery
– 1-year fellowship in surgical oncology
During your time in surgical oncology, you will learn how to perform a wide variety of cancer-related surgeries. You will also learn how to manage the many complications that can occur after cancer surgery.
Becoming a surgical oncology will require a great deal of dedication and hard work. However, if you are passionate about helping cancer patients, this can be an incredibly rewarding career choice.
The first step to becoming a surgical oncologist is to obtain a degree in medicine. This can be done through a four-year medical school program after earning a bachelor’s degree. It’s also important to complete a residency in general surgery.
After completing the residency, the next step is to complete a fellowship in surgical oncology. During this time, the surgeon will learn about different types of cancer and how to surgically remove them. It’s also important to complete continuing education courses throughout your career as a surgical oncologist.
While in school, future surgical oncologists should study hard and do well on exams. They should also spend time shadowing a surgeon to get a feel for the job. Finally, they should volunteer at a hospital or clinic to gain experience working with cancer patients.
The first step to becoming a surgical oncologist is to enroll in a medical school accredited by the Liaison Committee on Medical Education (LCME). Once enrolled, you will need to complete medical school, which typically takes four years.
Following medical school, you will need to complete a residency in surgery, which typically lasts three years. After your residency, you will need to complete a fellowship in surgical oncology, which typically lasts one year.
During your surgical oncology fellowship, you will learn how to perform a wide range of cancer-related procedures, including biopsies, tumor excision, and lymph node dissection. In addition, you will learn how to manage the complications that can occur after cancer surgery.
Becoming a surgical oncologist is not an easy task, but it is a rewarding one. If you are committed to helping cancer patients, then it may be the right career for you.

Dr. Shirley's work on biodiesel as a carbon cycle strategy is featured in the video https://vimeo.com/167313780.
The video https://vimeo.com/188396913 presents results of a study on biodiesel use in the United States. A paper outlining that study's results is available at http://pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/es5014923.
Dr. Martin gives his view in the video https://youtu.be/Csj0ZW28pw8 on whether biodiesel is ready for the mainstream.
Following is an excerpt from that video transcript.
Jim Martin: I think that this is a very good example of a technology that is moving into commercial scale because of environmental pressure, because there were some pretty big environmental groups that said we need to do this or else. If the petroleum companies had all of these new technologies and their engineers didn't think that they needed to move out of fossil fuels then they would ignore the whole situation. But because these environmental groups had put the pressure on them to do something that made them more competitive, it enabled a new market for this technology. So if the market grows a little bit and that grows the number of plants that are making it then it gets cheaper. That makes the price of this renewable energy product go down. Then people start to use it and it goes viral. And that's what we need to see happen with biodiesel.

I assume the reader has little or no knowledge of predicting the future as we don’t have any way of being able to predict the future. So, when you can talk about machines playing the roles of human brains, it shows that you are able to imagine the technological development in the future. The assignment asks you to read the two articles: (1) “The 2050 workforce: An AI and automation perspective and (2) “The 2050 Workforce: A Skills and Behavioral Change Perspective” and write a well-developed, 1500 to 1750-word discussion essay that includes the followings:  An introduction paragraph;  An introduction of your choice on how technology will transform workforce and how the economy will transform in the future.  A three-paragraph body that includes the following: A. An introduction presenting the two articles: “The 2050 Workforce: An AI and Automation perspective” and The 2050 Workforce: A Skills and Behavioral Change Perspective. B. An introduction to your choice on what you learn from reading the two articles together and how it will transform the future of work.  A conclusion paragraph that wraps up your essay.  Formatting:  The essay must be in Chicago style  Double-space between the lines  In 12 point Times New Roman font  Include a cover page that includes your name, student ID number, instructor’s name, course name, and the date  You must use a minimum of 7 scholarly articles from the CSU Online Library and the Ashford University Library (articles can be in form of books, book chapters, book reviews, etc.)

Here are five major elements that make up a competitive data scientist cover letter. By following these tips, you can make sure that prospective employers take the time to review your cover letter and consider your candidacy.
Use a concise, eye-catching headline: Your headline is the first thing that recruiters and employers see when they review your application. Make sure to include important information such as your name, qualifications, and the job position you are applying for.
Highlight your most valuable skills: In addition to your headline, include a table to outline your top skills and qualifications. This will provide the recruiter with an overview of your skills and help them decide if they need to contact you for a further discussion.
Showcase your personal brand: Use your cover letter to tell the employer about yourself and why you are a good fit for the job. Your cover letter should include relevant references, your resume, and information about your salary requirements.
Show that you are a good fit for the company culture: Talk about the company's values and culture and show that you are enthusiastic about the opportunity. Mention any unique skills or qualifications you may have that would make you a good fit for the role.
Include a personal contact information section: Finally, include your full name, phone number, and email address. This helps the recruiter and employer connect with you quickly and easily.

Relevant technical skills and skills: List your relevant skills, including coding, data analysis, machine learning, and statistical analysis.

For the past five weeks, you have been learning about the steps involved in conducting a SWOT analysis. As you continue to develop your strategic thinking skills, you will find that you begin to apply this knowledge instinctively while solving day-to-day problems. This week, you will complete our SWOT Analysis assignment. In addition, you will complete a discussion board about organizational goals and the role of information systems in strategy development.
MBA 600: Managing Information for Strategic Advantage is based on the premise that effective information management capabilities and the information systems (IS) environment in general are enablers that can be leveraged to help improve operations and competitive strategies. In this course, we define strategy as the way that a firm develops its competencies and systems to provide a superior value proposition to the firm’s clients. The mission and vision statements are the basis of the strategy for the firm and provide a guidepost to the actions that must be taken. In developing the vision, the strategic-thinking principles outlined by Tesla’s John Hagel III must be considered. The vision has the characteristics of the distant future and the near future.
The assignment is designed to offer practice and to help you understand how organizations use SWOT and other analysis tools to develop information systems strategies. These strategies influence many aspects of a firm’s operation. The assignment also tests your grasp of key aspects of IS strategy development for a firm.
SWOT Analysis Instructions
Create and fill out a SWOT Analysis for a new IS strategy.
The mission statement of the firm should be used to drive the discussion. Referring to the materials for this class and the firm selected:
Identify and fill in the SWOT using the template provided.
Determine the appropriate focus of an IT strategy, based on the material provided and the SWOT.
Assess the IS strategy choices and determine one key strategy.
Select a new IS strategy by answering the following questions:
Based on your analysis of the SWOT, what is the most viable IS strategy? Why?
Based on your understanding of the mission, what are your two key strategies? Why? What is the relationship between these strategies? How might you combine these strategies to produce a more powerful IS strategy?
Based on your strategies, create a new firm Vision that incorporates your SWOT analysis and two key strategies.
Besides the SWOT Analysis, what other information can be useful to understanding how the firm makes its final information systems strategic decisions? How does this relate to the competitive advantage?
Create a 5- to 7-page report in Word format. Apply APA standards to cite appropriately.

€˜. 3. In 1897, it was estimated that nearly 16 million cattle died from hoof-and-mouth disease, which quickly spread the epidemic throughout Europe. Because these millions of cattle died from one disease, the price of butter and beef quickly shot up, and many people were forced to eat more eggs.
However, chickens still died as a result of this outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease, which was later contained with the help of antibiotics. Chicken is a lean meat and it can be a healthy choice because it provides protein without being packed with saturated fat.
A pound of chicken breast has just over 100 calories and 38 grams of protein. As for saturated fat content, a pound of chicken breast is just under 2 grams. However, you must consume the meat in moderation if you want to keep your heart healthy.
Chicken breast fat content
The chicken breast is the main source of chicken meat and contains between 6% and 10% fat and is considered lean meat. The meat is usually sold deboned and skinless and comes mainly from broilers.
The lower fat content of chicken breast makes it an ideal cut for many people and it is considered to be richer in protein than other kinds of meat.
Chicken breast fat percentage
For example, a serving of chicken breast breast has about 100 calories. The total fat content of 35 grams is approximately 28 grams, most of which are unsaturated fats. The amount of saturated fat per serving is about 6 grams.
If you want to cut back on saturated fat, you should always buy skinless chicken and choose white meat over dark meat.
If you are trying to lose weight, it is also a good idea to try to reduce your intake of saturated fat while increasing your intake of protein.
There is a lot of confusion between fats and cholesterol in the foods we eat. While the two work hand in hand to transport vitamins and help us use energy, they also play an equally important role in inflammation and the development of chronic conditions, like heart attacks and strokes.
When it comes to our health, we generally categorize fats into good fats and bad fats, the latter of which is also known as bad cholesterol, or LDL cholesterol. The high cholesterol levels associated with unhealthy lifestyle choices may be a contributing factor to the development of heart disease.
The role of healthy fats
The two types of foods that contain good fats are plant fats and animal fats. When it comes to our overall health, foods that contain healthy fats are considered good sources of energy and help our bodies absorb vitamins and minerals. They also help our bodies use energy from our food and keep us feeling full.
Fats that help the body maintain hormone levels are called essential fats, such as Omega-3. These essential fats are important for healthy living and are vital for bone development and the health of our skin and organs.
Our body can synthesize essential fatty acids from omega-3 in our diets, but we get them from seafood and some plant-based foods, such as olive oil.
As you probably know, fats can have positive and negative effects on our health. Eating foods that are high in saturated fats and trans fats is linked to a higher risk of coronary heart disease, stroke, diabetes, obesity, and depression, while unsaturated fats help to maintain a healthy heart.
Healthy Fats for Weight Loss and Good Health
The type of fats (or the amount) we consume does matter. Research shows that too much added fat, especially unhealthy fats like trans fats and sugar-sweetened drinks, can lead to weight gain and other adverse health risks such as heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes.
The best way to reduce your risk is to cut down on saturated fats and replace them with unsaturated fats (mainly polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fats). METHODS: In a crossover design, elite 18- to 20-yearold male athletes completed two resistance training (RT) and two resistance and cardiorespiratory (CR) exercise sessions per week for eight weeks in an acute phase of HIIT versus matched aerobic interval training of the same time and intensity. Exercise was performed in two separate supervised aerobic workouts. The intensity (VO2 r max), volume (kilograms), and type (resistance, RT; or resistance and cardiorespiratory, CR) of exercise chosen at baseline and following the acute phase determined the type and sequence of exercise for the 8-week period. This was followed by two further phases, a post-acute resistance and aerobic training to determine post-testing effects of a combined, resistance and cardiorespiratory training program. RESULTS: The RT group increased 1RM by 25%, and the CR group by 15% whereas no such increase in RT or CR performance was seen in the HIIT group. No statistically significant changes in VO2 max and Vmax-k cal/min were observed in either group although the CR group had the greatest improvement in the work efficiency ratio (from 1.5 to 1.7). No safety concerns were observed during these protocols. CONCLUSION: The feasibility of an RT program was established in our selected athletes. The CR training program was too intensive for our athletes so they were unable to attain the required training volume of 40--50 minutes of training per week. However, the aerobic and resistance training was similar in terms of the total training stimulus (volume: 408 minutes versus 414 minutes; intensity: 75% VO2 r max versus 75% VO2 max ). In light of recent research into the effects of combined aerobic and strength training and the relatively low number of athletes who use RT programs for fitness and performance enhancement, our findings suggest that aerobic training alone (or combined with CR training) is sufficient to deliver a considerable training stimulus and result in significant increases in strength and power. TRIAL REGISTRATION: This study is registered in the Current Controlled Trials Registry (ISRCTN Registration no. ISRCTN52829929).

Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) was used to induce inflammation. EA was performed to improve the body's immune function. Our study included four experimental groups, i.e., the two EA groups and the two control groups (PBS, no LPS or LPS, no EA). No significant differences in body weight were observed between the experimental groups. The activities of SOD (16.70Â±1.73 versus 18.35Â±3.69 IU/g Â· min; P=0.364) and GSH-R (0.555Â±0.069 versus 0.641Â±0.073â€…nmol/tissue/120â€…s; P=0.792) were not significantly affected in the liver and kidney tissues of rats in any of the experimental groups. An increase in SOD activity in the kidney of rats in the LPS+EA group (18.57Â±1.25â€…IU/g Â· min) was also observed. There were no statistically significant differences in the bodyweight gain of the experimental rats in EAc, LPS+LPSAc, and EAc+LPSr groups within a single training day, but the changes in bodyweight gain were significantly different among the four groups of rats. Bilateral and Unilateral Electromyostimulation Training During a 20-Min High-Intensity Cycle Exercise Program
Full Text Available Background: It is important to understand the effect of training and exercise intensity, type of exercise, and electromyostimulation (EMG training (ET protocols on the response in muscle activity and performance of sportsmen during high-intensity exercise and also to understand the physiological mechanisms underlying sports performance. Materials and Methods: Fifteen elite male badminton players (mean age 22 Â± 2 years, stature 180.04 Â± 6.0 cm; body weight 71.59 Â± 7.4 kg participated in this study. The training program was designed as a progressive unilateral stepwise cycle ergometer exercise (20-min sessions. A second exercise and training session was done using the identical exercise protocol on the contralateral side. During one session, both legs were tested to observe the effects of single-leg EMG training (ET. The ET group, 5 sessions in a week, for 6 weeks performed quadriceps exercises (90% of maximum voluntary EMG. The control (CON group, 7 sessions, for 6 weeks performed standard aerobic exercise sessions. After the exercise sessions were completed, the muscle activity of the rectus femoris (RF was measured by a linear encoder. Result: The results demonstrated significant improvements in both groups in muscle strength and performance as well as significant reductions in heart rate and blood lactate levels following the completion of ET. However, there was no additional benefit to performing ET unilaterally after a single-leg exercise protocol. Conclusion: Based on this study, we suggest that it is beneficial to perform ET during exercise.

Atherton, Philip J; Murgatroyd, Cary L; Battin, Richard L; Peake, Jonathan M; Hargreaves, Mark; Hawley, John; Burke, Louise M; Cureton, Keith J; Petherick, Helen S
There is a paucity of data on the comparative effectiveness of interval training strategies targeting 3 vs 12 months of adaptation. We hypothesized that an equivalent level of adaptation/improvement in aerobic capacities could be obtained either after 3 or 12 months of high intensity interval training (HIIT), and that 3 months of HIIT is equally efficacious in comparison to more traditional endurance training. The study was divided into two phases, for 20 minutes per session (Phase 1: HIIT12, HIIT3, and CON HIIT12 groups trained for 1 and 3 months, respectively; CON HIIT3 group, n = 12, trained 3 times per week for 12 weeks; CON HIIT12 group, n = 19, trained 3 times per week for 12 months). We hypothesized that improvements in maximal oxygen uptake (VO(2max)), time to exhaustion and peak respiratory exchange ratio (Peak RER) would not differ significantly. Participants completed 3 submaximal (50% VO(2max)) maximal-cycle exercise tests during Phase 1 and 3. VO(2max) was measured with an incremental cycle ergometer testing protocol at peak VO(2) (aerobic capacity assesment), time to exhaustion (aerobic capacity submaximal assessment) and Peak RER (aerobic capacity assessment). Improvements in VO(2max), time to exhaustion and Peak RER were not different between HIIT3 and HIIT12. However, HIIT3 vs HIIT12 group showed an increase in time to exhaustion (6.5 vs 4.2%, P HIIT protocols and traditional endurance training programs for 3 and 12 months respectively may be equally efficacious in improving aerobic capacities. This may be of importance in prescription of interval training for maximal and submaximal aerobic training adaptations.
An aerobic exercise to decrease low back pain among workers in office-based jobs with or at-risk for physical demand disabilities.
Coleman, Michael G; Wetz, Kathleen E; Goulart, Maria M; Chow, Joyce C; Vinciguerra, Megan M; Huber, Kristi M; Mehta, Ruchita; Smyers, Matthew L
The present investigation (1) identified a 10-week workplace ergonomic intervention designed to decrease low back pain (LBP) among adults who have or are at-risk for developing physical demand disabilities at work, and (2) examined the effects of an office-based exercise intervention compared with no intervention on pain and disability among workers with or at-risk for disabling LBP. Low back pain (LBP) presents a significant problem for the workplace. Although ergonomics have been shown to reduce LBP, they are not designed for long-term use. Thus, a workplace behavioral intervention approach was used to modify sedentary behaviors among adults with or at-risk for physical demand disabilities. A multi-site, matched-control trial with a sample of workers (NÂ =Â 132) was conducted to compare the effectiveness of two different 10-week office exercise interventions: Exercise Intervention Group (nÂ =Â 64), and Control Intervention Group (nÂ =Â 68). The Exercise Intervention Group received 17-minute interval-based exercise breaks throughout the day. The Control Intervention Group was informed of the study findings, but no exercise recommendations were provided. Measures at baseline and the end of 10-weeks included a demographic report, an injury history report, and three versions of the Rapid Assessment of Disability (RAD) scale which included disability (sickness) component scores, pain/function ratio, self-rated disability, and pain intensity. Significant reductions were found in disability (sickness) component scores, and pain/function ratio among the Exercise Intervention Group compared with the Control Intervention Group. Significant improvements were found in pain/function ratio only among the Exercise Group. The present investigation identified an office-based ergonomics intervention designed to decrease LBP among adults with or at-risk for developing disabling LBP.
